An mRNA vaccine is a type of vaccine that uses a small piece of genetic material called messenger RNA (mRNA) to instruct cells in the body to produce a protein that is found on the surface of the virus. This protein is then recognized by the immune system as foreign, and the immune system mounts a response to destroy it. 

The mRNA vaccine does not contain the actual virus, but rather a blueprint for the immune system to recognize and fight the virus. It is like sending an email to the immune system with a picture of the virus and instructions on how to destroy it. Once the immune system has received this message, it can quickly and efficiently respond to any future encounters with the virus. 

The mRNA vaccine is also like a Snapchat message in that it disappears after it has been used. Once the mRNA has instructed the cells to produce the viral protein, it is quickly broken down and eliminated from the body. This means that the vaccine does not permanently alter the genetic material of the cells, and there is no risk of long-term side effects. 

Overall, the mRNA vaccine is a remarkable technology that has revolutionized the field of vaccine development. It offers a safe and effective way to protect against infectious diseases, without the need for live viruses or harmful chemicals.

Herd immunity is the point at which enough people in a population are immune to a disease that it can no longer spread easily. This means that even those who are not immune are protected because the disease cannot find enough hosts to continue spreading. 

Polio and smallpox were both highly contagious diseases that could cause severe illness, disability, and even death. Before vaccines were developed, these diseases were widespread and caused significant harm. 

Vaccines work by introducing a weakened or dead form of the disease into the body, which triggers an immune response. This response creates immunity to the disease, meaning that if the person is exposed to the disease in the future, their immune system can quickly recognize and fight it off. 

Through widespread vaccination campaigns, enough people became immune to polio and smallpox that the diseases could no longer spread easily. This led to their eradication, meaning that they no longer exist in the wild and do not pose a threat to human health. 

In summary, polio and smallpox were eradicated by vaccines because they were able to create herd immunity, even though the diseases themselves never reached that point naturally.
